metadata.title: The effect of incidence functions on the dynamics of a quarantine/isolation model with time delay

body_text.text: The aim of this study is to assess the roles of time delay (to model the incubation period of a disease) and the choice of incidence function in the transmission dynamics of a communicable disease in the presence of quarantine (of exposed individuals) and isolation (of individuals with disease symptoms). Quarantine and isolation measures have been widely used, over the decades, to control the spread of diseases such as yellow fever, smallpox, measles, ebola, pandemic influenza, diphtheria, plague, cholera, and, more recently, severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) [1], [2], [3], [4], [5], [6], [7], [8], [9]. To achieve the main objective of this study, the autonomous quarantine/isolation presented in [10] will be extended to incorporate time delay and two different incidence functions. The functional forms of the incidence functions to be considered are derived on the basis of the framework described below.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Let S(t),I(t) and N(t) denote the number of susceptible individuals, the number of infectious individuals and the total size of the population at time t, respectively. Further, let β(N) be the average number of contacts sufficient for transmitting infection (effective contact rate). Then, the force of infection, given by β(N)I/N, represents the average number of contacts that a susceptible individual makes with infectious individuals per unit time. If β(N)=βN (i.e., the contact rate depends on the total population, N), then the incidence function g1(I)=βI is called mass action incidence. If β(N)=β (a constant), then the incidence function g2(I)=βI/N is called standard incidence [11], [12]. These two functions are widely used in the modeling the transmission dynamics of the human diseases [13], [14]. Another widely used incidence function is the Holling type II incidence function, given by g3(I)=βI1+ωI, with ω>0, [15], [16], [17], [18]. The non-linear incidence function of type g3(I) was first introduced by Capasso and Serio [15], in their study of the cholera epidemic in Bari, Italy. The main justification for using such a functional form of the incidence function stems from the fact that the number of effective contacts between infective individuals and susceptible individuals may saturate at high infective levels due to crowding of infective individuals, or due to the preventive measures taken by (and behavioral changes of) the susceptible individuals in response to the severity of the disease [16], [17], [18].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The paper is organized as follows. The model with standard incidence is formulated in Section 2. The existence and global asymptotic stability of its disease-free equilibrium (DFE), as well as the existence of its endemic equilibrium point (EEP), are established in Section 3. The model with the Holling type II incidence function is formulated and analyzed in Section 4. The permanence of the disease is also established for this model.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Using the generalized Leibnitz rule of differentiation [25], the model (1) can be rewritten as a system of delayed differential difference equation given by (3)dSdt=Π−βS(t)I(t)N(t)−μS(t),dEdt=βS(t)I(t)N(t)−e−τ(μ+σ)βS(t−τ)I(t−τ)N(t−τ)−(σ+μ)E,dIdt=e−τ(μ+σ)βS(t−τ)I(t−τ)N(t−τ)−(γ1+ϕ+μ+δ1)I(t),dQdt=σE(t)−(α+μ)Q(t),dHdt=αQ(t)+ϕI(t)−(γ2+μ+δ2)H(t),dRdt=γ1I(t)+γ2H(t)−μR(t). The basic qualitative properties of the model (3) will now be investigated.
body_text.section: Basic properties ::: Model formulation: standard incidence

body_text.text:
Lemma 1
The solution
(S(t),E(t),I(t),Q(t),H(t),R(t))
of the system (3)
, with the initial data (2)
, exists for all
t≥0
and is unique. Furthermore,
S(t)>0,E(t)>0,I(t)>0,Q(t)>0,H(t)>0
, and
R(t)>0
for all
t≥0
.
body_text.section: Basic properties ::: Model formulation: standard incidence

body_text.text:
ProofSystem (3) can be written as (where a dot represents differentiation with respect to t) X˙=f(t,Xτ), where X=(S(t),E(t),I(t),Q(t),H(t),R(t))∈C. Since f(t,X) is continuous and Lipschitz in X, it follows, by the Fundamental Theory of Functional Differential Equations [26], that the system (3) has a unique solution (S(t),E(t),I(t),Q(t),H(t),R(t)) satisfying the initial data (2).It is clear from the first equation of the model (3) that dSdt≥−[βS(t)I(t)N(t)+μ]S(t), and so S(t)≥S(0)exp{−∫0t[βS(u)I(u)N(u)+μ]du}>0,for all t>0.
Similarly, it follows from the third equation of the system (3) that I(t)>0 for all t>0. Since the second equation of (3) is equivalent to the second equation of (1), it follows (by using the fact that S(t)>0 and I(t)>0 for all t>0, together with the fact that all the parameters of the model are positive) that E(t)=∫t−τtβS(x)I(x)e−(μ+σ)(t−x)N(x)dx>0. Furthermore, using the same approach as for S(t) above, it can be shown that Q(t)>0,H(t)>0 and R(t)>0 for all t>0. □
body_text.section: Basic properties ::: Model formulation: standard incidence

body_text.text:
Lemma 2
The closed set
D={(S,E,I,Q,H,R)∈R+6:S+E+I+Q+H+R≤Πμ}
is positively invariant.
body_text.section: Basic properties ::: Model formulation: standard incidence

body_text.text: ProofAdding all the equations of the model (3) gives (4)dNdt=Π−μN−(δ1I+δ2H). Since dN/dt≤Π−μN, it follows that dN/dt≤0 if N≥Π/μ. Thus, N(t)≤N(0)e−μt+Πμ(1−e−μt). In particular, N(t)≤Π/μ if N(0)≤Π/μ. Hence, the region D is positively invariant. Further, if N(0)>Π/μ, then either the solution enters D in finite time, or N(t) approaches Π/μ asymptotically. Hence, the region D attracts all solutions in R+6. □
body_text.section: Basic properties ::: Model formulation: standard incidence

body_text.text: In this section, the possible existence and stability of endemic (positive) equilibria of the model (3) will be explored.
body_text.section: The existence of an EEP ::: Global stability of the DFE

body_text.text: Let E1S=(S∗∗,E∗∗,I∗∗,Q∗∗,H∗∗,R∗∗) represent any arbitrary endemic equilibrium point of the model (3), so N∗∗=S∗∗+E∗∗+I∗∗+Q∗∗+H∗∗+R∗∗. Solving the equations of the model (3) at the steady state gives (10)S∗∗=Πλ∗∗+μ,E∗∗=λ∗∗S∗∗(1−e−τ(σ+μ))σ+μ,I∗∗=e−τ(σ+μ)λ∗∗S∗∗γ1+ϕ+μ+δ1,Q∗∗=σE∗∗α+μ,H∗∗=αQ∗∗+ϕI∗∗γ2+μ+δ2,R∗∗=γ1I∗∗+γ2H∗∗μ, where (11)λ∗∗=βI∗∗N∗∗. For computational convenience, the expressions in (10) are rewritten in terms of λ∗∗S∗∗ as below: (12)E∗∗=λ∗∗S∗∗(1−e−τ(σ+μ))σ+μ,I∗∗=e−τ(σ+μ)λ∗∗S∗∗γ1+ϕ+μ+δ1,Q∗∗=P1λ∗∗S∗∗,H∗∗=P2λ∗∗S∗∗,R∗∗=P3λ∗∗S∗∗, where P1=σ(1−e−τ(σ+μ))(σ+μ)(α+μ),P2=αP1γ2+μ+δ2+ϕe−τ(σ+μ)(γ2+μ+δ2)(γ1+ϕ+μ+δ1),P3=γ1e−τ(σ+μ)μ(γ1+ϕ+μ+δ1)+γ2P2μ. Substituting the expressions in (12) into (11) gives (13)λ∗∗S∗∗+λ∗∗S∗∗(1−e−τ(σ+μ))λ∗∗σ+μ+λ∗∗e−τ(σ+μ)λ∗∗S∗∗γ1+ϕ+μ+δ1+λ∗∗P1λ∗∗S∗∗+λ∗∗P2λ∗∗S∗∗+λ∗∗P3λ∗∗S∗∗=βe−τ(σ+μ)λ∗∗S∗∗γ1+ϕ+μ+δ1. Dividing each term in (13) by λ∗∗S∗∗ (and noting that, at the endemic steady state, λ∗∗S∗∗≠0) gives
body_text.section: The existence of an EEP ::: Global stability of the DFE

body_text.text: (14)1+P4λ∗∗=βe−τ(σ+μ)γ1+ϕ+μ+δ1=R0S. Since P4=1−e−τ(σ+μ)σ+μ+e−τ(σ+μ)γ1+ϕ+μ+δ1+P1+P2+P3≥0, it follows from (14) that (15)λ∗∗=R0S−1P4>0,whenever R0S>1. The components of the endemic equilibrium, E1S, can then be obtained by substituting the unique value of λ∗∗, given in (15), into the expressions in (10). Thus, the following result is established.
body_text.section: The existence of an EEP ::: Global stability of the DFE

body_text.text:
Lemma 4
The model (3) has a unique endemic (positive) equilibrium, given by
E1S
, whenever
R0S>1
.
body_text.section: The existence of an EEP ::: Global stability of the DFE

body_text.text:
Although not proven here, numerical simulations of the model (3) suggest that the EEP (E1S) of the model (3) is asymptotically stable for R0S>1 (Fig. 3
). It should be mentioned, however, that the solutions depicted in Fig. 3 did not converge to zero, as they appear to (see Fig. 4
for a blow up of the tail end of Fig. 3). In other words, Fig. 3, Fig. 4 show convergence of the solutions to the unique EEP, E1S, of the model (3) for the case R0S>1. The following conjecture is suggested:Conjecture 1
The unique EEP,
E1S
, of the model (3) is LAS whenever
R0S>1
.
body_text.section: The existence of an EEP ::: Global stability of the DFE

body_text.text: In summary, the model (3) has a globally asymptotic stable disease-free equilibrium whenever R0S<1, and it has a unique endemic equilibrium whenever R0S>1. These results are consistent with those reported for the corresponding autonomous (non-delayed) quarantine/isolation model in [10]. In other words, adding time delay to the non-delayed quarantine/isolation model in [10] does not alter its qualitative (equilibrium) dynamics. The next task is to determine whether or not the dynamics of the non-delayed quarantine/isolation model in [10] is affected by the combined use of time delay and the substitution of the standard incidence function with the Holling type II incidence function. This is considered below.
body_text.section: The existence of an EEP ::: Global stability of the DFE

body_text.text:
The delayed system (16) has the same DFE, E0, as the system (3). Further, the invariant region, D, holds for system (16) as well. The GAS property of the DFE of the system (16) will be explored using the methodology given in [29]. Define R0H=βΠe−τ(μ+σ)μ(γ1+ϕ+μ+δ1). The proof is based on using the following result. Lemma 5[29]
Consider the following delay differential equation:
(17)u˙=au(t−τ)1+ωu(t−τ)−bu(t),u(θ)=ϕ(θ)≥0,θ∈[−τ,0),ϕ(0)>0
where
a,b
and
ω
are positive constants,
τ≥0
; then:
(i)
Eq.
(17) has a trivial equilibrium
u=0
and it is globally asymptotically stable if
a<b
.
(ii)
If
a>b
, Eq.
(17) has a unique positive equilibrium
u∗=a−bωb
which is globally asymptotically stable.
body_text.section: Global stability of the DFE ::: The model with Holling type II incidence

body_text.text:
Theorem 2
The DFE of the model (16)
, given by (5)
, is GAS in
D
whenever
R0H<1
.
body_text.section: Global stability of the DFE ::: The model with Holling type II incidence

body_text.text:
ProofLet R0H<1. Furthermore, let (S(t),E(t),I(t),Q(t),H(t),R(t)) be any positive solution of the system (16) with the initial data (2). Since R0H<1, it is clear that (18)βe−τ(μ+σ)Π/μ<γ1+ϕ+μ+δ1. Since S(t)≤Π/μ in D for all t>0, it follows from the second equation of (16) that (19)I˙≤βΠe−τ(μ+σ)I(t−τ)μ[1+ωI(t−τ)]−(γ1+ϕ+μ+δ1)I(t). Consider, next, the auxiliary (with equality) equation associated with the inequality (19) (where u is a dummy variable) (20)u˙=βΠe−τ(μ+σ)u(t−τ)μ[1+ωu(t−τ)]−(γ1+ϕ+μ+δ1)u(t). Using Item (i) of Lemma 5, together with Eq. (18), in (20) gives limt→+∞u(t)=0. Thus, it follows from (19), using the comparison theorem [28], that lim supt→+∞I(t)=0. Thus, for any ϵ>0 sufficiently small, there exists a T>0 such that if t>T, then I(t)<ϵ. Using S≤Π/μ in D and I<ϵ, for t>T, in the second equation of (16) (note that g(I) is monotone increasing) gives E˙≤βΠϵμ(1+ωϵ)−(σ+μ)E. Furthermore, by the comparison theorem, lim supt→+∞E(t)≤βΠϵμ(σ+μ)(1+ωϵ). Since ϵ is arbitrary, it follows (by setting ϵ→0) that lim supt→+∞E(t)=0. Hence, for ϵ1>0 small, there exists a T1>T such that if t>T1, then E(t)<ϵ1. Using E(t)<ϵ1, for t>T1, in the fourth equation of (16) gives Q˙≤ϵ1σ−(α+μ)Q, and so lim supt→+∞Q(t)≤ϵ1σα+μ. Hence, lim supt→+∞Q(t)=0. In a similar way, it can be shown that lim supt→+∞H(t)=0andlim supt→+∞R(t)=0.
Finally, it follows from the first equation of (16), for t>T, that S˙≥Π−βSϵ1+ωϵ−μS, so, using the comparison theorem, lim inft→+∞S(t)≥Π(1+ωϵ)μ+ϵ(β+ωμ). Hence (by letting ϵ→0) lim inft→+∞S(t)≥Πμ. Additionally, since lim supt→+∞S(t)≤Πμ in D it follows that limt→+∞S(t)=Πμ. Thus, limt→+∞(S(t),E(t),I(t),Q(t),H(t),R(t))=(Πμ,0,0,0,0,0)=E0.
 □ The epidemiological implication of the above result (Theorem 2) is that the combined use of quarantine and isolation can lead to disease elimination if the two interventions can bring (and keep) the threshold quantity, R0H, to a value less than unity (i.e., the condition R0H<1 is necessary and sufficient for disease elimination).
body_text.section: Global stability of the DFE ::: The model with Holling type II incidence

body_text.text:
By solving for τ from the equation R0H=1 (and noting Theorem 2), the following result can be obtained. Lemma 6
The DFE of the model (16)
, given by (5)
, is GAS in
D
whenever
τ>ln[βΠμ(μ+ϕ+γ1+δ1)](1σ+μ)=τcH
.
body_text.section: Global stability of the DFE ::: The model with Holling type II incidence

body_text.text:
In other words, like in the case of system (3), the disease will be eliminated from the community if and only if τ>τcH. Fig. 5
depicts the numerical results obtained by simulating the model (16) using the parameter values in Table 3 and various initial conditions for the case τ>τcH(R0H<1). It is evident from this figure that all solutions converged to the DFE, E0 (in line with Theorem 2 and Lemma 6).
body_text.section: Global stability of the DFE ::: The model with Holling type II incidence

body_text.text:
Let E1H=(S∗∗;E∗∗;I∗∗;Q∗∗;H∗∗;R∗∗) represent any arbitrary endemic equilibrium of the model (16). Solving the equations of the model (16) at the steady state gives (21)S∗∗=Π(1+ωI∗∗)μ(1+ωI∗∗)+βI∗∗,E∗∗=β(1−e−(σ+μ)τ)S∗∗I∗∗σ+μ,S∗∗=(1+ωI∗∗)(γ1+ϕ+μ+δ1)βe−(σ+μ)τ,Q∗∗=σE∗∗α+μ,H∗∗=ϕI∗∗+αQ∗∗γ2+μ+δ2,R∗∗=γ1I∗∗+γ∗∗H∗∗μ. Equating the first and third equations of (21), and solving for I∗∗ in terms R0H, gives (22)I∗∗=R0H−1μ(β+ωμ)(γ1+ϕ+μ+δ1)2>0,whenever R0H>1. Substituting for I∗∗ from (22) into the first equation of (21) gives (23)S∗∗=ωΠe−(σ+μ)τ+(γ1+ϕ+μ+δ1)e−(σ+μ)τ(β+ωμ). It follows from (21) (noting from (22) and (23) that both I∗∗ and S∗∗ are positive if R0H>1) that E1H∈R+6 whenever R0H>1. Thus, the following result is established. Lemma 7
The model (16) has a unique endemic (positive) equilibrium, given by
E1H
, whenever
R0H>1
.
body_text.section: The existence of an EEP ::: The existence of an EEP and disease permanence ::: The model with Holling type II incidence

body_text.text:
The permanence of the disease will now be explored in the context of the model (16). That is, the objective is to determine whether or not the number of infectious cases in the population will persist above a certain positive number for a long time period (for the case when R0H>1). Theorem 3
If
R0H>1
, then for any solution of (16) with the initial data (2)
, there exists a positive number
ν=e−τ(γ1+ϕ+μ+δ1)I∗∗
, such that
lim inft→∞I(t)≥ν
.
body_text.section: Permanence of the disease ::: The existence of an EEP and disease permanence ::: The model with Holling type II incidence
Permanence of the disease ::: The existence of an EEP and disease permanence ::: The model with Holling type II incidence

body_text.text: The epidemiological implication of Theorem 3 is that the number of infectious cases will persist in the population (as t→∞) above a certain positive number (ν) whenever R0H>1.
body_text.section: Permanence of the disease ::: The existence of an EEP and disease permanence ::: The model with Holling type II incidence

body_text.text: Here, the global stability of the EEP, E1H, of the model (16) will be explored. It is convenient to define D0={(S,E,I,Q,H,R)∈D:E=I=Q=H=R=0}.
body_text.section: Global stability of the EEP ::: The model with Holling type II incidence

body_text.text:
Theorem 4
The unique endemic equilibrium of the model (16)
, given by (21)
, is GAS in
D∖D0
if
R0H>1
and
ωΠe−τ(σ+μ)>ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1
.
body_text.section: Global stability of the EEP ::: The model with Holling type II incidence

body_text.text:
ProofThe proof of Theorem 4 is based on using a comparison argument and an iteration technique, as given in [29], [34].Let (S(t),E(t),I(t),Q(t),H(t),R(t)) be any solution of (16) with initial conditions given by (2). Further, let S∞=lim inft→∞S(t),S∞=lim supt→∞S(t),E∞=lim inft→∞E(t),E∞=lim supt→∞E(t)I∞=lim inft→∞I(t),I∞=lim supt→∞I(t),Q∞=lim inft→∞Q(t),Q∞=lim supt→∞Q(t)H∞=lim inft→∞H(t),H∞=lim supt→∞H(t),R∞=lim inft→∞R(t),R∞=lim supt→∞R(t). The goal is to show that S∞=S∞=S∗∗,E∞=E∞=E∗∗,I∞=I∞=I∗∗,Q∞=Q∞=Q∗∗,H∞=H∞=H∗∗,andR∞=R∞=R∗∗. It follows from the first equation of (16) that S˙(t)≤Π−μS, and so, by the comparison theorem, lim supt→∞S(t)≤Π/μ.
Let U1S=Π/μ. Thus, for sufficiently small ϵ>0, there exists a T1>0 such that S(t)≤U1S+ϵ for t>T1. It follows from the third equation of (16) that, for t>T1+τ, (29)I˙(t)≤βe−τ(σ+μ)(U1S+ϵ)I(t−τ)1+ωI(t−τ)−(ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1)I(t). Consider the auxiliary equation of (29): (30)u˙(t)=βe−τ(σ+μ)(U1S+ϵ)u(t−τ)1+ωu(t−τ)−(ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1)u(t). Since R0H>1, it follows that, for sufficiently small ϵ>0,βe−τ(σ+μ)(U1S+ϵ)>(ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1). Hence, by Item (ii) of Lemma 5 and (30), limt→∞u(t)=βe−τ(σ+μ)(U1S+ϵ)−(ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1)ω(ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1). Thus, by the comparison theorem, I∞=lim supt→∞I(t)≤βe−τ(σ+μ)(U1S+ϵ)−(ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1)ω(ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1), and so I∞≤βe−τ(σ+μ)U1S−(ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1)ω(ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1). Similarly, let U1I=βe−τ(σ+μ)U1S−(ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1)ω(ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1). Then, for sufficiently small ϵ>0, there exists a T2>T1+τ such that I(t)≤U1I+ϵ for t>T2. It follows from the first equation of (16), for t>T2, that S˙(t)≥Π−μS−β(U1I+ϵ)1+ω(U1I+ϵ), and so, by the comparison theorem, S∞=lim inft→∞S(t)≥Π[1+ω(U1I+ϵ)]μ+(β+μω)(U1I+ϵ). Hence, S∞≥L1S, where L1S=Π[1+ωU1I]μ+(β+μω)U1I. In other words, for sufficiently small ϵ>0, there exists a T3>T2+τ such that S(t)≥L1S−ϵ for t>T3. It follows from the third equation of (16), for t>T3+τ, that I˙(t)≥βe−τ(σ+μ)(L1S−ϵ)I(t−τ)1+ωI(t−τ)−(ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1)I(t), and so (by considering the auxiliary equation) u˙(t)=βe−τ(σ+μ)(L1S−ϵ)u(t−τ)1+ωu(t−τ)−(ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1)u(t). Hence, it follows from Item (ii) of Lemma 5 (since R0H>1) that limt→∞u(t)=βe−τ(σ+μ)(L1S−ϵ)−(ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1)ω(ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1), and the comparison theorem gives I∞=lim inft→∞I(t)≥βe−τ(σ+μ)(L1S−ϵ)−(ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1)ω(ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1). Hence, for sufficiently small ϵ>0, there exists a T4>T3+τ such that I(t)≥L1I−ϵ for t>T4, where L1I=βe−τ(σ+μ)L1S−(ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1)ω(ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1).
Using S(t)≤U1S+ϵ,I(t)≤U1I+ϵ, S(t)≥L1S−ϵ and I(t)≥L1I−ϵ in the second equation of (16), for t>T4+τ, gives E˙≤β(U1S+ϵ)(U1I+ϵ)1+ω(U1I+ϵ)−βe−τ(σ+μ)(L1S−ϵ)(L1I−ϵ)1+ω(L1I−ϵ)−(σ+μ)E. Hence, by the comparison theorem, E∞=lim supt→∞E(t)≤β(U1S+ϵ)(U1I+ϵ)[1+ω(U1I+ϵ)](σ+μ)−βe−τ(σ+μ)(L1S−ϵ)(L1I−ϵ)[1+ω(L1I−ϵ)](σ+μ). Therefore, for sufficiently small ϵ>0, there exists a T5>T4+τ such that E(t)≤U1E+ϵ for t>T5, where U1E=βU1SU1I(1+ωU1I)(σ+μ)−βe−τ(σ+μ)L1SL1I(1+ωL1I)(σ+μ).
Similarly, by using S(t)≤U1S+ϵ,I(t)≤U1I+ϵ,S(t)≥L1S−ϵ and I(t)≥L1I−ϵ in the second equation of (16), for t>T4+τ, we have E˙≤β(L1S−ϵ)(L1I−ϵ)1+ω(L1I−ϵ)−βe−τ(σ+μ)(U1S+ϵ)(U1I+ϵ)1+ω(U1I+ϵ)−(σ+μ)E, and so E∞=lim inft→∞E(t)≥β(L1S−ϵ)(L1I−ϵ)[1+ω(L1I−ϵ)](σ+μ)−βe−τ(σ+μ)(U1S+ϵ)(U1I+ϵ)[1+ω(U1I+ϵ)](σ+μ). Hence, for sufficiently small ϵ>0, there exists a T6>T5+τ such that E(t)≥L1E−ϵ for t>T6, where L1E=βL1SL1I(1+ωL1I)(σ+μ)−βe−τ(σ+μ)U1SU1I(1+ωU1I)(σ+μ). Using E(t)≤U1E+ϵ in the fourth equation of (16), for t>T5, gives Q˙(t)≤σ(U1E+ϵ)−(α+μ)Q, and so Q∞=lim supt→∞Q(t)≤σ(U1E+ϵ)α+μ. Thus, for sufficiently small ϵ>0, there exists a T7>T6+τ such that Q(t)≤U1Q+ϵ for t>T7, where U1Q=σU1Eα+μ.Similarly, by using E(t)≥L1E−ϵ in the fourth equation of (16), for t>T6, we have Q˙(t)≥σ(L1E−ϵ)−(α+μ)Q, and Q∞=lim inft→∞Q(t)≥σ(L1E−ϵ)α+μ. Thus, for sufficiently small ϵ>0, there exists a T8>T7+τ such that Q(t)≥L1Q−ϵ for t>T8, where L1Q=σL1Eα+μ. Using I(t)≤U1I+ϵ and Q(t)≤U1Q+ϵ in the fifth equation of (16), for t>T7, gives H˙(t)≤α(U1Q+ϵ)+ϕ(U1I+ϵ)−(γ2+μ+δ2)H, and H∞=lim supt→∞H≤α(U1Q+ϵ)+ϕ(U1I+ϵ)γ2+μ+δ2. Thus, for sufficiently small ϵ>0, there exists a T9>T8+τ such that H(t)≤U1H+ϵ, for t>T9, where U1H=αU1Q+ϕU1I(γ2+μ+δ2). Similarly, it follows by using I(t)≥L1I−ϵ and Q(t)≥L1Q−ϵ in the fifth equation of (16), for t>T8, that H˙(t)≥α(L1Q−ϵ)+ϕ(L1I−ϵ)−(γ2+μ+δ2)H, and so H∞=lim inft→∞H≤α(L1Q−ϵ)+ϕ(L1I−ϵ)γ2+μ+δ2. Hence, for sufficiently small ϵ>0, there exists a T10>T9+τ such that H(t)≥L1H−ϵ for t>T10, where L1H=αL1Q+ϕL1Iγ2+μ+δ2.Using I(t)≤U1I+ϵ and H(t)≤U1H+ϵ in the last equation of (16), for t>T9, gives R˙≤γ1(U1I+ϵ)+γ2(U1H+ϵ)−μR. Hence, R∞=lim supt→∞R(t)≤γ1(U1I+ϵ)+γ2(U1H+ϵ)μ. Thus, R∞≤U1R, where U1R=γ1U1I+γ2U1Hμ. Using I(t)≥L1I−ϵ and H(t)≥L1H−ϵ in the last equation of (16), for t>T10, gives R˙≥γ1(L1I−ϵ)+γ2(L1H−ϵ)−μR, and so (by the comparison theorem) R∞=lim inft→∞R(t)≥γ1(L1I−ϵ)+γ2(L1H−ϵ)μ. Hence, R∞≥L1R, where L1R=γ1L1I+γ2L1Hμ.Continuing in this manner leads to the following sequences: (31)UnS=Π[1+ωLn−1I]μ+(β+μω)Ln−1I,LnS=Π[1+ωUnI]μ+(β+μω)UnI,UnI=βe−τ(σ+μ)UnS−(ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1)ω(ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1),LnI=βe−τ(σ+μ)LnS−(ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1)ω(ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1),UnE=βUnIUnS(1+ωUnI)(σ+μ)−βe−τ(σ+μ)LnILnS(1+ωLnI)(σ+μ),LnE=βLnILnS(1+ωLnI)(σ+μ)−βe−τ(σ+μ)UnIUnS(1+ωUnI)(σ+μ),UnQ=σUnE(α+μ),LnQ=σLnE(α+μ),UnH=αUnQ+ϕUnI(γ2+μ+δ2),LnH=αLnQ+ϕLnI(γ2+μ+δ2),UnR=γ1UnI+γ2UnHμ,LnR=γ1LnI+γ2LnHμ.
Finally, since LnS≤S∞≤S∞≤UnS,LnE≤E∞≤E∞≤UnE,LnI≤I∞≤I∞≤UnI,LnQ≤Q∞≤Q∞≤UnQ, LnH≤H∞≤H∞≤UnH and LnR≤R∞≤R∞≤UnR, the proof is concluded by showing that limn→∞UnS=S∗∗=limn→∞LnS,limn→∞UnI=I∗∗=limn→∞LnI,limn→∞UnE=E∗∗=limn→∞LnE,limn→∞UnQ=Q∗∗=limn→∞LnQ,limn→∞UnH=H∗∗=limn→∞LnH,limn→∞UnR=R∗∗=limn→∞LnR. Using the first four sequences of (31), it is easy to see that the sequence Un+1S can be written in terms of UnS as (32)Un+1S=ω2Π2e−2τ(σ+μ)UnSk2+e−τ(σ+μ)(β+ωμ)[ωΠe−τ(σ+μ)−k]UnS, where k=ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1. Furthermore, it can be shown that whenever ωΠe−τ(σ+μ)>k, the sequence UnS is monotone as follows: Un+1S−UnS=[ωΠe−τ(σ+μ)−k][ωΠe−τ(σ+μ)+k−(β+ωμ)e−τ(σ+μ)UnS]UnSk2+e−τ(σ+μ)(β+ωμ)[ωΠe−τ(σ+μ)−k]UnS. Since S∗∗≤UnS, it follows that Un+1S−UnS≤[ωΠe−τ(σ+μ)−k][ωΠe−τ(σ+μ)+k−(β+ωμ)e−τ(σ+μ)S∗∗]UnSk2+e−τ(σ+μ)(β+ωμ)[ωΠe−τ(σ+μ)−k]UnS,=0(since S∗∗=ωΠe−τ(σ+μ)+ke−τ(σ+μ)(β+ωμ)). Thus, limn→∞UnS exists.Let M=limn→∞UnS. Then, it follows from (32) that M=ω2Π2e−2τ(σ+μ)Mk2+e−τ(σ+μ)(β+ωμ)[ωΠe−τ(σ+μ)−k]M, and so M=limt→∞UnS=ωΠe−τ(σ+μ)+ke−τ(σ+μ)(β+ωμ)=S∗∗. Taking the limit as n→∞ of both sides of the third sequence of (31) gives limn→∞UnI=βe−τ(σ+μ)S∗∗−(ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1)ω(ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1)=I∗∗. Similarly, taking the limits of both sides of the remaining sequences in (31), and using the previous results, gives limn→∞LnS=S∗∗,limn→∞LnI=I∗∗,limn→∞UnE=limn→∞LnE=E∗∗limn→∞UnQ=limn→∞LnQ=Q∗∗,limn→∞UnH=limn→∞LnH=H∗∗,limn→∞UnR=limn→∞LnR=R∗∗. Hence, limt→∞(S(t),E(t),I(t),Q(t),H(t),R(t))=E1H. □
body_text.section: Global stability of the EEP ::: The model with Holling type II incidence

body_text.text:
Theorem 4 shows that the disease will persist in the population whenever R0H>1. Here, too, by solving for τ from R0H>1, the following result can be shown. Lemma 8
The unique endemic equilibrium of the model (16)
, given by (21)
, is GAS in
D∖D0
if
τ<ln[βΠμ(μ+ϕ+γ1+δ1)](1σ+μ)=τc
and
ωΠe−τ(σ+μ)>ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1
.
body_text.section: Global stability of the EEP ::: The model with Holling type II incidence

body_text.text:
Theorem 4 shows that the disease will persist in the population provided that R0H>1(τ<τc) and ωΠe−τ(σ+μ)>ϕ+γ1+μ+δ1. Thus, Lemma 6, Lemma 8 suggest that τ=τc is a sharp epidemiological threshold that governs the persistence (τ<τc) and elimination (τ>τc) of the disease in the population. Fig. 7
shows a time series plot of the total number of infected individuals for various initial conditions. This figure clearly shows convergence of the solutions to the EEP for the case τ<τc(R0H>1) (in line with Theorem 4 and Lemma 8). Fig. 8
depicts of the total number of cases as a function of time for various values of τ. This figure shows a decreasing number of cases with increasing values of delay parameter τ. That is, the longer individuals stay in the exposed class, the lower the disease burden.
body_text.section: Global stability of the EEP ::: The model with Holling type II incidence
Global stability of the EEP ::: The model with Holling type II incidence

body_text.text: A deterministic quarantine/isolation model with time delay is considered, subject to two incidence functions, namely standard incidence and the Holling type II incidence function. The main findings of this study are summarized below: (i)The model with standard incidence function, given by (3), has a globally asymptotically stable disease-free solution whenever a certain epidemiological threshold quantity (R0S) is less than unity (Theorem 1). Furthermore, this model has a unique positive endemic equilibrium whenever the threshold quantity (R0S) exceeds unity (Lemma 4).(ii)The model with Holling type II incidence function, given by (16), has a globally asymptotically stable disease-free solution whenever its associated epidemiological threshold quantity (R0H) is less than unity (Theorem 2). This model has a unique positive endemic equilibrium whenever the threshold quantity (R0H) exceeds unity (Lemma 7). Furthermore, the model system is permanent whenever R0H>1 (Theorem 3). The unique endemic equilibrium of the model (16) is globally asymptotically stable under certain conditions (Theorem 4).
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: In summary, the theoretical analyses in this study show that adding time delay to and/or replacing the standard incidence function by a Holling type II incidence function in the autonomous (non-delayed) quarantine/isolation model in [10] does not alter the qualitative dynamics (as regards the elimination or persistence of the disease) of the non-delayed model considered in [10]. In other words, the theoretical results in this study show that the quarantine/isolation model with time delay (τ>0) and standard or non-linear incidence function of Holling type II has essentially the same qualitative (equilibrium) dynamics as the corresponding autonomous quarantine/isolation model (τ=0) with the standard incidence function considered in [10].
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: Numerical simulations of the delayed model with the standard incidence function show that the associated disease burden decreases with increasing time delay (τ). Furthermore, models with time delay seem to be more appropriate for modeling the SARS epidemic than those without time delay (regardless of which of the incidence functions is used).
body_text.section: Conclusions
